bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
I would most respectfully call your attention to the enclosed copy of a letter from the Rev.R.H.Nassan American Missionary at Coises.
The statements there in an unfortunately but too tone. No less than two weeks ago a ship load of negroes, was smuggled from the neighborhood of Rama (a village some fifty or sixty miles distant) to Princes island, and I find on inquiry that similar transactions on of monthly, if not of weekly occurence.
I was also informed but yesterday, by Henry A. Boardman, a trader, long established at this place, and who has for years supplied the American vessels with barkwood, ivory, ebony, + that two of his boats had ]been plundered of a valuable cargo, while on a trading voyage up the
come
come, and that on a former occasions when he had suffered a considerable loss from the departures of the natives, that his representations, had not been listened to, by the French authorities to whom he had applied for
This Sir, and those mentioned by the Rev. R.H.Nassan, on but a fear of the many instances which have occured when American citizens have either been punished or maltreated without the power of obtaining vessels.
I would also call your attention to my late despatch of the 17th >unclear> in reference to the diffculties of the American Bante Roebuck in which instance an American man of war would have been most desirable. Independent of these facts,
I believe, and it is the opinion of the missionaries and other American citizens residing on the coast that the presence of an American manifest war would be very desirable that it would be beneficial to then and add to the dignity of the nature.
Treaing that this despatched will need with a favorable receptoire
I have the honor to be Very Respectfully your obdient servt Augustus Peret U.S. Cont. Agent
